> From a component user view point I'd still like to see a 
> concise descr=
iption of the prerequisites without having to 
> dig into the component cod=
e or even the unit testing code... 
> ... though I realise I'm in danger of=
 reopening the javadoc v 
> unit test discussion :-)

The way I see this is=
 that there is a difference between a published
(and public) API, and a sys=
tem API.

Whereas the system API is one that is subject to frequent refacto=
rings,
and governs the internal shape of the system, the published API is t=
hat
which interfaces with third parties (be it as a producer or as a
consum=
er).  As such, this should be a very stable API, and changes to it
should g=
o through controlled @deprecation process spanning perhaps
several releases=
 (to allow clients to catch up).

I am in favor of explicit documentation f=
or published APIs, and am quite
comfortable with unit tests alone (or, God =
forbid! no documentation at
all) for system APIs (*).

Manuel Amago.
mailto=
:mamago@...

(*)  If you find yourself having to dive into system A=
PIs, you are
probably better off understanding the internals anyway, withou=
t needing
any documentation.  Unit tests could come in handy if you make an=
y
modifications, or to check that any changes you make don't disturb the
ex=
isting system.
